mnemonic: SOU sounds like 'SO' - 'SO I am who I am!'
grammar_notes: First person singular of 'ser' - used for PERMANENT identity profession nationality
cultural_note: Often used to introduce yourself: 'Sou o João' (I'm João)
tip: No article needed with professions: 'Sou médico' not 'Sou um médico'

mnemonic: ÉS ends with S = Speaking to Someone informal (friend)
grammar_notes: Informal 2nd person - accent distinguishes from archaic 'es'. Use with 'tu'
cultural_note: Used with 'tu' - informal settings like friends and family. In Porto more common than Lisbon
tip: Notice the acute accent (é) - indicates stressed syllable

mnemonic: É = Everyone uses this one! He/she/it/formal you
grammar_notes: Used with ele/ela/você - most common form in daily conversation
cultural_note: This form covers he/she AND formal you (você) - very versatile!
tip: This single form works for he she it and formal you!

mnemonic: SOMOS = SO-MOOSE (we are like a group of moose!)
cultural_note: In casual speech 'A gente é' (singular!) often used instead of 'Nós somos'
tip: Remember: nós somos BUT a gente é (a gente takes singular verb!)

mnemonic: SÃO - like 'sound' without the D - they SOUND like many
grammar_notes: Third person plural - used with eles/elas/vocês
cultural_note: Most versatile plural form - covers multiple people in any context

mnemonic: SER = Stay the Same Forever (permanent states)
grammar_notes: Infinitive form - use for PERMANENT states: identity origin characteristics
cultural_note: SER vs ESTAR is crucial! SER = what you ARE / ESTAR = how you FEEL or WHERE you are
tip: Remember: SER = 'Situation Endures Regularly' - permanent things!
example2_en: I want to be a doctor.
